properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow continues today. Snow will continue today, with an additional 5 centimetres expected. This will result in total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm by this evening. Local total snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are possible near the Minnesota Border. However in general, the criterion for snowfall warning is not expected to be reached across Northwestern Ontario. Strong easterly winds with gusts to 60 km/h will also generate occasional blowing snow giving reduced visibilities. The snow may become mixed with freezing drizzle at times, especially for areas close to Lake Superior. Hazardous winter driving conditions due to low visibility in occasional heavy snow and blowing snow, and accumulating snow on untreated roads are expected. The heaviest snowfall associated with this Colorado Low will remain south of the international border where Winter Storm Warnings are in effect. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-12T19:01:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-12T11:02:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4041419896.2019
Area: Fort Frances - Emo - Rainy River, Seine River Village - Mine Centre, Atikokan - Shebandowan - Quetico Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow today into tonight. Snow will continue today into tonight with total accumulations of 10 to 15 cm likely by Saturday morning. Strong easterly winds with gusts to 50 km/h will also generate occasional blowing snow giving reduced visibilities. The snow may become mixed with freezing drizzle at times, especially for areas close to Lake Superior. Hazardous winter driving conditions due to low visibility in occasional heavy snow and blowing snow, and accumulating snow on untreated roads are expected. The snow will end by Saturday morning as the Colorado Low moves away towards James Bay and Northwestern Quebec. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain continues late this morning, but will change to rain or drizzle early this afternoon. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. Ice accretion of 2 to 5 millimetres is possible. This winter weather is associated with a Colorado Low that will track across Northeastern Ontario today. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Update: Flood Watch Continued For All Points Along The Roseau River
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a Flood Watch for all points along the Roseau River due to expected high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-04-13T11:15:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-04-12T11:24:25-05:00, B6EF896F-E95B-94A7-B238-F843D5A3653E
Area: All points along the Roseau River
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall today. Rain will continue today with isolated thunderstorms also likely this morning. Significant rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm are possible by this afternoon especially in areas that see a thunderstorm. Local ponding on streets and low lying areas is possible. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District Office. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-12T20:59:45-00:00

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Winter Weather Travel Advisory is in effect for today. Snow and ice pellets will switch over to freezing rain this morning then to rain near noon today. Most areas will receive another 2 to 5 cm of snow and ice pellets before the transition to freezing rain. Motorists should be prepared for difficult winter driving conditions due to rapidly accumulating snow and low visibilities in snow. Note that a freezing rain warning is also in effect. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-12T17:59:10-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A mixed bag of wintery precipitation today. Snow, mixed with ice pellets and possibly some freezing rain will briefly change over to rain or a rain and wet snow mix later today as temperatures edge above the zero degree mark. Precipitation will change back to snow this evening. Total snow and ice pellet amounts will range from just a couple centimetres in the Kapuskasing and Little Abitibi areas up to 10 cm in a swath of regions from near Hearst to the Marathon - Schreiber area. Poor winter driving conditions are expected. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. This messy winter weather is courtesy of a Colorado Low which will track from the US Midwest across Lake Superior to James Bay by Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-12T22:34:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-12T14:35:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1746598532.2019
Area: Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, Marathon - Schreiber, Fraserdale - Pledger Lake, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls, Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a Flood Warning on the Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway channel inlet due to high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong easterly winds continue to cause blizzard conditions near the Richardson Mountains. Winds are forecast to ease somewhat near midday and reintensify this evening. The winds will likely remain strong through to at least Sunday morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-13T09:27:07-00:00

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Areas of dense fog developed in central Alberta overnight. Highway cameras show fog along sections of the QEII Highway and parts of Anthony Henday Drive. The visibility will improve as the fog dissipates later this morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
